Award.AwardTitle: ARTS: Collaborative Research: Understanding the relationships and radiation of Old World Croton (Euphorbiaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will provide a better understanding of the species diversity and evolutionary relationships within one of the world's largest flowering plant genera, Croton (Euphorbiaceae). Many Croton species are important ecologically, used medicinally, or considered endangered, but the large number of species and worldwide distribution has hampered previous efforts to fully understand the systematics of the genus. This study by researchers at the University of Puerto Rico Mayaguez and the University of Michigan builds on a previous project investigating Croton species in North, Central and South America and now focuses on producing a comprehensive phylogeny and classification system for the estimated 450 Croton species native to Asia, Africa and Madagascar. Undergraduate researchers and graduate students, including members of under-represented groups, will be involved in all aspects of the study including plant biology workshops for high school teachers within Puerto Rico to highlight the importance of plants to a large and broad audience.

This study will investigate the systematics of the estimated 450 Croton species in Africa, Asia and Madagascar using a combination of field, herbarium and molecular techniques. Phylogenetic relationships will be reconstructed using a combination of at least 10 nuclear, chloroplast and mitochondrial markers to provide necessary the evolutionary framework to investigate the tempo and mode of biogeographical evolution within Croton, with an emphasis on the colonization and dispersal throughout the Old World. Descriptions, images and additional information for different Croton species, including a comprehensive monograph of the genus, will be disseminated freely online through the Encyclopedia of Life and Catalogue of the Vascular Plants of Madagascar webpages. This study will also produce a DNA barcode database for the Malagasy species to help identify these species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the 400+ species of the large plant genus Croton from the Old World in an effort to understand their taxonomic complexity and then to pool our worldwide data to achieve a better understanding of how this large lineage of plants evolved and spread across the warmer parts of the globe. The project built upon previous work that used molecular phylogenetic data to construct a modern taxonomic framework for the 800+ species from the New World. A particular focus of this award was the flora of Madagascar, because that single island off the eastern coast of Africa accounts for over a third of the species of Croton in the Old World. This project combined extensive field studies in Madagascar and other parts of the Old World tropics, morphological study of specimens that were collected as part of the project or else were previously collected and deposited in major botanical museums, and extensive DNA sequencing, including the first genomic studies in the genus.

Based on hundreds of new field-based collections of plant specimens and tissue for DNA extraction, we produced a revised synopsis of the Madagascan species of Croton, totaling 132 recognized species, including several that were described as new in accompanying papers. This excludes, however, about twenty other new species for the island that we are in the process of describing and publishing. Many of these species are photographically documented and all are incorporated into the Tropicos database hosted at the Missouri Botanical Garden. Our molecular studies confirm that Croton likely reached Madagascar from ancestors on mainland Africa, but Madagascar has also been a source for populating other areas such as the Mascarene Islands and the Comoros Archipelago in the Indian Ocean, as well as at least three back-dispersals to mainland Africa. In the case of the 29 Australian species of Croton, they are the result of at least four separate colonizations of the continent from other parts of Asia, and they have all been assigned to sections of Old World Croton based on both morphological and molecular characters. Across Africa and Asia, areas that are poorer in species than Madagascar and Australia, we have sampled a wide array of species and initiated a Hyb-Seq genomic approach in order to produce a robust phylogeny of Croton across the entire geographic range of the genus. Based on our extensive work in Madagascar, we have committed to producing a full-length monograph of the species of Croton there, along with conservation assessments for each species, with additional private foundation support.

This collaborative project brought together a senior scientist, a junior faculty member who was granted tenure during the grant, as well as international collaborators. The project trained and supported a postdoctoral fellow for two years in Michigan; several Master?s students at the University of Puerto Rico-Mayag?ez; and over 10 undergraduate research students. The project also supported molecular biology and bioinformatics training workshops for over 50 undergraduate students from the University of Puerto Rico-Mayag?ez.

This project has extended the well-established and highly-productive collaboration between North American and Latin American taxonomists to workers in Australia, Asia, and Africa. With this, Croton is on track to be one of the giant plant genera with one of the most complete and best-curated records in GenBank and Tropicos.
